content.description: Splitter finger/ring locks. Grade depends on finger size. Down climb or hop off with big enough pad.
Small to big hands. Jam straight up.
Sidepulls and finger/ring locks. Chos fest. Mantle to finish and downclimb.
content.location: Canal & Cermak (South East side of intersection)

content.description: Great side pull climbing. Crux is halfway up when the wall shifts and you must cross to pull from the other side. Wall is very deteriorated at crux. Avoid loose gravel at crux move, the loose chunk of stone at the top, and the rusty railing at the top out. Enjoy the skyline view at the top and walk down the loading ramp.
content.protection: Multiple crash pads and possibly something to hold them down. You'll be in a wind tunnel.
content.location: Canal & 25th (South East side of intersection.) At the bottom of the railroad loading ramp. For best access in climbing, try toward the evening or on a Sunday when the railroad yard is not operating to avoid any police disturbance calls. Due to the highway overpass and the yard above the crack, climbing is basically impossible if its rained in the last few days.. the crack will be wet.

content.description: Intended stand start. V0 version involves compression climbing using both sides of the crack to the I beam. The climb is your down-climb
content.location: Canal & 23rd (South East side of intersection) The ground surrounding the crack is a garden kept by a woman in the neighborhood. Climbing here is not accessible during the warmer months out of respect to her garden. Come back when its cold and enjoy.

content.description: Crimpy sidepulls into flaring pocket to thin fingers. Mantle ledge and then downclimb.

Several cracks are scattered along Canal St, stretching from 22nd to 26th. The wall is made of concrete and is chos in some places. All cracks are right off the road so be ready for spectators or pick a quiet time to climb.
